content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–5.

Based on past musical productions, a theater predicts selling \(400-8p\) tickets when each ticket is sold at \(p\) dollars.

  1. Answer questions a–g to complete the middle column in the table to find out how many tickets the theater expects to sell and what revenues it expects to receive at the given ticket prices.

Ticket price (dollars)

Number of tickets sold

Revenue (dollars)

\(5\)

\(360\)

\(1800\)

\(10\)

a. _____

  

\(15\)

b. _____

  

\(20\)

c. _____

  

\(30\)

d. _____

  

\(45\)

e. _____

  

\(50\)

f. _____

  

\(p\)

g. _____

  

    1. When the price is \($10\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 320 tickets sold when the price is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 320. There are 320 tickets sold when the price is $10 per ticket. 

    1. When the price is \($15\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 280 tickets sold when the price is $15 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 280. There are 280 tickets sold when the price is $15 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($20\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 240 tickets sold when the price is $20 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 240. There are 240 tickets sold when the price is $20 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($30\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 160 tickets sold when the price is $30 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 160. There are 160 tickets sold when the price is $30 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($45\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 40 tickets sold when the price is $45 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 40. There are 40 tickets sold when the price is $45 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($50\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! There are 0 tickets sold when the price is $50 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. There are 0 tickets sold when the price is $50 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \(p\) per ticket, what is the number of tickets sold?

Correct! \(400-8p\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(400-8p\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer questions a-g to complete the right column in the table to find out what revenues the theater expects to receive at the given ticket prices.

Ticket price (dollars)

Number of tickets sold

Revenue (dollars)

\(5\)

\(360\)

\(1800\)

\(10\)

  

a. _____

\(15\)

  

b. _____

\(20\)

  

c. _____

\(30\)

  

d. _____

\(45\)

  

e. _____

\(50\)

  

f. _____

\(p\)

  

g. _____

    1. When the price is \($10\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $3,200 when the price is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3,200. The revenue is $3,200 when the price is $10 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($15\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,200 when the price is $15 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,200. The revenue is $4,200 when the price is $15 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($20\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $20 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,800. The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $20 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($30\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $30 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4,800. The revenue is $4,800 when the price is $30 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($45\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is $1,800 when the price is $45 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1,800. The revenue is $1,800 when the price is $45 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \($50\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is zero when the price is $50 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The revenue is zero when the price is $50 per ticket.

    1. When the price is \(p\) per ticket, what is the revenue in dollars?

Correct! \(p(400-8p)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(p(400-8p)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For which ticket price, listed in the table, will the theater earn no revenue?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The revenue is zero when the ticket price is $50.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 50. The revenue is zero when the ticket price is $50. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Calculate the lowest price of a ticket that the theater should sell the tickets for if it must earn at least \($3,200\) in revenue to break even (to not lose money) on the musical production. (The calculated value may not be listed in the table.)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The lowest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $10 per ticket.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 10. The lowest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $10 per ticket. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Calculate the highest price of a ticket that the theater should sell the tickets for if it must earn at least \($3,200\) in revenue to break even (to not lose money) on the musical production. (The calculated value may not be listed in the table.)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The highest price the theater should charge to make at least $3,200 and break even is $40 per ticket. Although not shown in the table, we can calculate that when \(p\) is $40, the expected revenue is \(40(400-8(40))\) or \(40 \cdot 80\), which is $3,200.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 40. The highest price the theater should charge to at least make $3,200 and break even is $40 per ticket. Although not shown in the table, we can calculate that when \(p\) is $40, the expected revenue is \(40(400-8(40)\) or \(40 \cdot 80\), which is $3,200. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A company sells running shoes. If the price of a pair of shoes in dollars is \(p\), the company estimates that it will sell \(50,000-400p\) pairs of shoes.

    Which expression represents the revenue in dollars from selling running shoes if a pair of shoes is priced at \(p\) dollars?

Correct! \((50,000-400p) \cdot p\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \((50,000-400p) \cdot p\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Use the following to answer questions 7–9.

The function \(f\) represents the revenue in dollars the school can expect to receive if it sells \(220-12x\) coffee mugs for \(x\) dollars each.

Here is the graph of \(f\).

  1. Select three statements that describe this situation.

Correct! The school expects to sell 160 mugs if the price is $5 each. The school will earn about $1,000 if it sells the mugs for $10 each. The revenue will be more than $700 if the price is between $4 and $14.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The school expects to sell 160 mugs if the price is $5 each. The school will earn about $1,000 if it sells the mugs for $10 each. The revenue will be more than $700 if the price is between $4 and $14. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. To the nearest hundred dollars, what is the maximum revenue for the mugs?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 1000

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 1,000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which is the approximate domain?

Correct! \(0 \leq x \leq 18\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(0 \leq x \leq 18\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
